column4:
Introduction

About the course
Understanding how communications, media and cultural change shape daily life is vital in todayâs world. Our BA (Hons) Media, Culture and Society examines media, popular culture and wider social and political changes from within firmly sociological frameworks.

You will be introduced to the central sociological issues in understanding and researching media, culture and society. At later levels you develop a deeper sociological understanding of crucial cultural and media phenomena, including popular film, news journalism, youth subcultures, the Information Society, Scottish culture, social movements, and artâs relationship to society. In the Honours year you get the chance to carry out a supervised piece of social science research into an aspect of culture, media and society you find particularly interesting. Teaching is informed by staff research interests in the areas of the moving image, the press, gender, lifestyle and subcultures, science and risk, national identity, education, and policy processes.

What you study
Stage 1
Introduction to media & cultural studies; media and celebrity culture; reading sociology; history and social change; âraceâ, media & crime; criminology; globalization and development.

Stage 2
Youth and consumption; news, truth & power; classical sociological theory; work, welfare and consumption; sociology of Hollywood cinema; researching the Information Society.

Stage 3
Propaganda and PR; media and crime; popular culture & the media; gender; contemporary social theory; social movements; sexualities; Scottish culture and society; crime and punishment; sociology of journalism.

Stage 4
Contemporary cultural analysis; sociology of cultural technologies; realism, narrative and myth; science & society; discourse analysis; the sociology of the city; gender and crime.

How you learn
In the first two years, lectures and reading help develop your general knowledge of the subject area. Class-based tutorials and seminars provide an opportunity to discuss the ideas and topics. You will spend around approximately 10-12 hours per week attending classes, in addition to around approximately 36 hours of private study. In later years of the course you are encouraged to adopt a more independent and self-directed approach to learning under the guidance of your lecturers.

How you are assessed
Assessment on this course includes essay writing, presentations and examinations. Assessments are typically completed on an individual basis with an opportunity to work in groups, particularly in later years of study. Assessments gradually build-up your writing and analytical skills, culminating in a self-directed Honours dissertation.

Core Themes

Text and Context
This degree will provide you with the skills to critically evaluate significant media texts and their relationship to contemporary social issues. These are related to areas of specialist interest within the sociology division and include modules such as: Introduction to Media and Culture, News Truth and Power, Popular Film Genres, Cultural Theory, Popular Culture and the Media. These media oriented modules will complement modules with a broader focus such as: Youth in Modern Britain, Sex and Sexuality, Sociology of Crime and Deviance, Ethics and Society, The City and Modern Life, Sociologies of Scotland and The Sociology of the Body.

Social Conflict and Social Control
One of the key themes informing the degree concerns questions associated with the location of power and control in society. There are a number of exciting courses specifically concerned with issues such as these. For example, Key Questions in Modern Society, Social Movements and Political Protest, Sociology of the Environment, Gender and Women Studies and Penal Institutions.

Globalisation
The idea that modern societies are undergoing a period of rapid social change leading to a breakdown in the distinctions between different cultures and the growing dominance of culture is one of the most important contemporary debates within sociology. These processes affect important areas of social life such as: work and business, culture and entertainment, national identity, state power and control and the individualâs place within society.

This degree course is informed throughout by these ongoing debates and it is anticipated that students studying this degree will be equipped with a critical awareness necessary to understand a dynamic social world. By the end of the degree you will have gained an appreciation of both social and cultural theory. You will have developed your critical reasoning skills and be able to collect and analyse a range of qualitative data.

Career Opportunities:

In a society where an understanding of culture and communications is of central importance this course develops the skills that employers increasingly require. By fostering your intellectual, analytical, and research abilities the degree prepares you for a wide range of people-centred careers, including teaching, research, journalism, community education and arts, public relations, and public service.

MatureIn order to determine an applicant's ability to benefit from study or research at the University of Abertay Dundee, a range of standard and flexible criteria will be used in considering applications.

In most circumstances applications will be considered in light of the following:

Applications from mature students are assessed on the same criteria used for school leavers e.g. SQA Highers or GCE A Levels, where relevant school leaving qualifications exist. For those without standard entry qualifications, consideration is given to experience gained as well as professional qualifications and other forms of learning that could provide evidence of ability to benefit from a particular course.

The successful completion of approved access courses (such as those offered by Dundee College in association with the universities of Abertay, Dundee and St Andrews) provides significant evidence of ability to benefit from study at Abertay.

For further advice please use our Got a Question section.

OverseasThe University makes offers of entry to courses based on qualifications offered worldwide. For undergraduate level entry, if you are studying the International Baccalaureate, you would be expected to achieve at least 26 points. We consider a variety of alternative qualifications on an individual basis. Examples of the qualifications accepted for entry from Overseas students in recent years include: Chinese High School Diploma, Malaysia Advanced Certificate of Education (STPM), European Baccalaureate, West African Senior Secondary School Certificate (WASSCE) with a minimum of 5 passes at B3 or better from external examination plus an accceptable level of pass in JAMB, Indian Secondary Certificate plus Indian Higher Secondary Certificate (10+2), Pakistan Secondary Certificate plus Pakistan Higher Secondary Certificate, Hong Kong Advanced Level Certificate (HKALE).

All applicants are required to provide certified proof of competence in English Language. The University's minimum requirements are IELTS 6.0 (with no band lower than 5.0), TOEFL CBT 223, TOEFL 563, TOEFL IBT 85 or a suitable equivalent qualification.

column4:
Transferable skills

While studying on this course you will gain a number of practical skills that are useful in any field of business, such as how to use email, type reports, build a database, and use the internet effectively as well as being introduced to specialised software relevant to your subject choices. You will also learn how to sift through vast quantities of detailed information quickly, and to present the important points in a concise and straightforward manner. As you progress through the degree course you will gain other incidental skills which will prove invaluable in any future working environment. These may include:
1. Learning how to learn effectively
2. Self-motivation
3. Assertiveness
4. Time management
5. Meeting deadlines
6. Problem solving
7. Analysis, synthesis, discrimination and judgement
8. Logical and reasoned thinking.

Teamwork

Being able to work as a member of a team is an important quality in a University student. Working in a team situation allows you to utilise your own personal strengths and to build upon areas where you are lacking by learning from other people. It also allows you to gain experience in leading discussions and delegating responsibility, as well as learning to become an effective listener â an important leadership quality which can sometimes be overlooked. Making a positive contribution to a joint project allows you to develop team-working skills.
Working together on coursework often allows you to form close friendships in your social life as you learn to listen to and trust other peopleâs judgements.
